Please choose 5 people that would create the most engaging dinner party.

Scoring Explanation:
The game is split into 1 rounds. Each round is different, and provides a way for each participant in the dinner party to score points.
At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.


Do not think through your answer. Answer immediately with "Answer: <person1>, <person2>, ... Done."

Scoring Explanation:
The game is split into 3 rounds. Each round is different, and provides a way for each participant in the dinner party to score points.
At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 2: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 3: [Most Common Interest] First, find the most commonly shared interest by number of people with any value in the interest, excluding interests which have been chosen in previous rounds (breaking ties alphabetically), and make it the topic for the round. Then, award each person their value in that interest in points.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.

At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Loudest Interest] In this round, we find the interest with the highest value among all guests which has not yet been discussed. This is the highest single value in a single interest that one person has. Break ties alphabetically by interest name. Then, each person is awarded their value in that interest in points.

Round 2: [Niche Interests] In this round, we find the three interests with lowest total values across all guests, meaning the lowest sum of interest among all guests, breaking ties alphabetically. Then, we award 3 bonus points to each guest for each of these niche interests they have.

Round 3: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 4: [Each Person Speaks] In this round, each person is awarded points equal to their highest interest in any topic which has not yet been discussed by the full group. If a person has no undiscussed interests, they get 0 points.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.


Do not think through your answer. Answer immediately with "Answer: <person1>, <person2>, ... Done."

Scoring Explanation:
The game is split into 4 rounds. Each round is different, and provides a way for each participant in the dinner party to score points.
At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Each Person Speaks] In this round, each person is awarded points equal to their highest interest in any topic which has not yet been discussed by the full group. If a person has no undiscussed interests, they get 0 points.

Round 2: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 3: [Focused Host Interest] In this round, one guest is chosen as the host. The host is the guest with the fewest number of interests (breaking ties alphabetically, and skipping people who have previously hosted a round). That host's largest interest (again, breaking ties alphabetically) is chosen as the topic for the round. Then, each guest gets points equal to their value in that topic.

Round 4: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.


Do not think through your answer. Answer immediately with "Answer: <person1>, <person2>, ... Done."

Scoring Explanation:

At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Most Common Interest] First, find the most commonly shared interest by number of people with any value in the interest (breaking ties alphabetically), and make it the topic for the round. Then, award each person their value in that interest in points.

Round 2: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 3: [Loudest Interest] In this round, we find the interest with the highest value among all guests which has not yet been discussed. This is the highest single value in a single interest that one person has. Break ties alphabetically by interest name. Then, each person is awarded their value in that interest in points.

Round 4: [Niche Interests] In this round, we find the three interests with lowest total values across all guests, meaning the lowest sum of interest among all guests, breaking ties alphabetically. Then, we award 7 bonus points to each guest for each of these niche interests they have.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.

Round 2: [Focused Host] In this round, the host is chosen as the guest with the fewest number of interests (breaking ties alphabetically, and skipping guests who have previously hosted a round). Then, each guest gets 2 points for each interest they share with the host.

Round 3: [Each Person Speaks] In this round, each person is awarded points equal to their highest interest in any topic which has not yet been discussed by the full group. If a person has no undiscussed interests, they get 0 points.

Round 4: [Most Common Interest] First, find the most commonly shared interest by number of people with any value in the interest (breaking ties alphabetically), and make it the topic for the round. Then, award each person their value in that interest in points.

Round 5: [Niche Interests] In this round, we find the three interests with lowest total values across all guests, meaning the lowest sum of interest among all guests, breaking ties alphabetically. Then, we award 6 bonus points to each guest for each of these niche interests they have.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.

Round 2: [Focused Host] In this round, the host is chosen as the guest with the fewest number of interests (breaking ties alphabetically, and skipping guests who have previously hosted a round). Then, each guest gets 5 points for each interest they share with the host.

Round 4: [Each Person Speaks] In this round, each person is awarded points equal to their highest interest in any topic which has not yet been discussed by the full group. If a person has no undiscussed interests, they get 0 points.

Round 4: [Focused Host] In this round, the host is chosen as the guest with the fewest number of interests (breaking ties alphabetically, and skipping guests who have previously hosted a round). Then, each guest gets 5 points for each interest they share with the host.

Round 5: [Talk about Cinema] This round is simple. Award each person their value in Cinema in points. (Or 0 if they don't have it)

Scoring Explanation:
The game is split into 4 rounds. Each round is different, and provides a way for each participant in the dinner party to score points.
At the end of the game, each participant's points are added together to score the dinner party as a whole.

Here are the rules for each round:

Round 1: [First Host] In this round, the alphabetically lowest guest is chosen as the host, excluding guests who have previously hosted a round. Then, each guest gets 2 points for each interest they share with the host.

Round 2: [Most Common Interest] First, find the most commonly shared interest by number of people with any value in the interest, excluding interests which have been chosen in previous rounds (breaking ties alphabetically), and make it the topic for the round. Then, award each person their value in that interest in points.

Round 3: [Focused Host] In this round, the host is chosen as the guest with the fewest number of interests (breaking ties alphabetically, and skipping guests who have previously hosted a round). Then, each guest gets 2 points for each interest they share with the host.

Round 4: [Well-Rounded Interests] In this round, each guest gets points based on how close their highest and lowest interest levels are. Each person gets points based on this formula: `max(0, 10 - (highest_score - lowest_score))`, ignoring 0s. A smaller gap means more points, encouraging well-rounded conversationalists.


The final score is the sum of all interest levels for these top 3 interests.
In all cases, if there is a tie between valid options, it goes to the interest or person with the name closest to the beginning of the alphabet.
Your goal is to maximize the total score of the dinner party, by choosing just the right group of people.
